title: 18-year-old sues Mass. town for allowing sex offender to operate business where she was assaulted
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Local News When renewing the license for Hillers Pizza, Hopkinton officials knew or should have known about owner Petros Sismanis’s criminal record, the lawsuit alleges.
A photo of the Town Offices on Main Street in downtown Hopkinton.
Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Staff, File By Abby Patkin January 14, 2026 | 4:23 PM 3 minutes to read ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: Massachusetts GOP gubernatorial candidates are bankrolling their own campaigns. Do you agree?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Tell Us Does self-funding give candidates a leg up in the competition, or risk alienating supporters and potential constituents?

Massachusetts GOP gubernatorial candidates, from left to right: former MBTA executive Brian Shortsleeve; former biotech executive Michael Minogue; and former state economic development secretary Mike Kennealy.

(Photos by Keith Bedford/Globe Staff; Sophie Park/Bloomberg; and Pat Greenhouse/Globe Staff) By Annie Jonas January 14, 2026 | 3:48 PM 2 minutes to read Despite being nearly a year away, the Massachusetts gubernatorial election is already front of mind — and front of wallet — for many candidates, particularly well-funded Republicans who are collectively pouring millions of their own dollars into their campaigns.

title: Another New England state edged out Mass. as the healthiest in the nation
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Health New Hampshire ranked as the healthiest state for the fourth consecutive year, with Vermont and Connecticut following Massachusetts in third and fourth, respectively.

title: Amid fears of escalation, local and state leaders remain stymied by feds over Burlington ICE facility
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Local News Reports of a large shipment of vehicles coming to the Burlington ICE facility are a "huge worry," the chair of the Burlington Select Board said.
